content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												This game goes against what historians say about what happened in the eastern front and gets it all wrong in the story line, everyting from Order 227 to Scorched Earth policy is potrayed wrongly but it's made by relic and relic is a canadian company. First off Order 227 is potrayed as this order that if soviet troops retreat they will be shot as soon as they make it back to their commander, in real life they would have been shot but only for desertion and they would have been given a warning before they were shot. Second the scorched earth policy is potrayed as an order given by stalin to destroy all buildings and material before retreating from your position, in real life building that wern't occupied by civillians were desginated for destruction and the material was to be used to slow the enemy advance. The only good thing about this game is the gameplay in multiplayer mode. And after this games failed launch were it recived heavy criticisem from eastern europeans, relic soon came out with the western front allies which really is just a new version of company of heroes one. what keeps this game going is the mountain of Steam workshop items that can be downloaded a good amount are good some are bad but there is maps, tuning packs that improve game play or give you diffrent/extra units and win condition where it modifies how you win a match.In world war 2 one shot from a ISU-152 was able to destroy a panzer 4 with one shot in this game a panzer 4's main 75mm gun with standard shell can rip apart a ISU when hitting the frontal armor when a the front armor of a ISU was able to defeat the 75mm shell.The AI DO NOT pay resource cost by this I mean if a machine gun and crew cost 300 man power the AI pays nothing I've been in matchs against AI that 1 minute into the match they have 4 MG's and like 10 squads of infantry where I have like 4 squads and 1 MG and I have spent all man power on these units and you could push the enemy back to their base and they have no resource income but they will still field a bunch of infantry and spawn a heavy tank.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												I was waiting for this game for a long time. Compared to the first CoH, it is a terrible game. It is not terrible because it is not the same, but it is terrible because it feels like the game was not made with much thought. There are so many DLCs, and the tech trees for each commander seems so limited, so much of variations on the same theme. The best commanders are only available as "pay to win". The matchmaking system is HORRIBLE. Why not just let me screen for games on a browser and join them? Why only let me select one choice for a match, when I may be open to several different types of games? Matchmaking systems should always be optional.The way they changed infantry and vehicle balance also made the game feel much more vehicle focused. Most infantry, even some antitank infantry, don't stand a chance against tanks. They just drop like flies, even under cover (though it might also be the hacking AI). The AT guns are also clunky and require just as much pop cap as a small or medium tank. The AI cheats like crazy for comp stomp games. Example: you cannot field any snipers because they will be killed magically by magic mortars and other freak shots. You can only play certain tactics against the AI, as all the other normal tactics will fail to their horrible hacks (worst than the first one, not even fun, why not put some more thought into AI?). Playing against the computer becomes an exercise in patience, and it is not fun.Even though I spent a pretty penny on this game and a few DLCs, and I really wanted to like this game, I have gone back to CoH original. Good luck to everyone else.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												The game itself seems like a fun concept with good graphics and realism but:Most of the game is locked out with purchase/DLC options including all single player campaign content.The tutorial is almost useless.There is apparently no map scrolling and clicking on the minimap to select a different area all the time is tedious and not accurate enough.I played through the single and small tutorial mission and enjoyed the game so far though all it teaches you to do is to move and select an enemy unit to fire on.The next screen was filled with Buy Now! Buy Now! Buy Now! Buy Now! missions... so I clicked to play the single player campaigns and only got two options. I tried Ardennes Assault and saw Purchase... So I went back and clicked the Russian one and got - yes, you guessed it - Purchase... So there's no single player campaign missions included with the game? Strike one and major fail in my opinion.I tried Theatre of War - Battles, Challenges and Co-Op Scenarios - which had 4 options. All of which had Purchase instead of start mission or something useful. Strike two.The only thing left was Online & Skirmish - Automatch vs Players seemed to work, but I had no interest in playing against other players when I really had no idea what I was doing yet. Three strikes.I tried Automatch vs AI but again it was multiplayer vs AI and I wanted to play solo.In my fifth and final attempt to actually play this game I tried Create Custom Game and I was finally able to create a game which had me vs an AI player. I had no idea what I was doing and failed quickly and horribly. I'm done.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												EDIT 1/15/2016:I have updated this review with a thumbs up to reflect the progress that this game has made over the past two years.I am very satisfied with this title as of now; it is a friendly experience to gamers that may not be familiar with RTS games.The Steam workshop adds an infinite amount of replayability for this tilte: camos, maps, mods.The graphics have been updated since release, and the game definitely runs a lot better at max setting on my pc.The game has been better balanced to actually giving the Allies a fair fighting change against the Axis powers.What has really made me happy about this game, is that I introduced a handful of my friends to it; firneds that do not normally enjoy RTS titles, yet for some strange reason this game calls out to them and allows them a fun gaming experience.The only 2 drawbacks, I would say, is the commander DLC and the matchmaking. While it is not exactly P2W, the DLC for commanders is a little expensive for recylced abilites jumbled up to fit playstyles. If, I may, suggest buying individual abilites and crafting your own doctrines and mixes using the abilities you have unlocked through war spoils and DLC. With minor restrictions, (only 2 call-ins or 2 artillery abilities for example) I feel this would ultimately bring about the best gaming experience to both seasoned players, and those contemplating on buying this title.The matchmaking, is by far, a little bit on the unbalanced side.I am prestige 1 level 75, and I constantly play against fresh level 20 players, and prestige 3 max level players ALL OF THE TIME. The teams are grossly inbalanced and the game usually ends with victory to the more experienced team.All in all, this is a wonderful game to pick up.The solo player is nice, the coop is nice, the multiplayer is wonderful, but the most important aspect is the custom match ability to play against AI and friends; this alone ties this game together to be absolutely worth the effort. ___________________________________________________________________________________I don't really know how to explain my feelings towards this game.At one end I really enjoy the History aspect of the game, being one of the bloodiest battles in human existence.At the other, this game feels like it took one giant step back from the original Company of Heroes that we RTS fans have fallen in love with. The graphics are appealing, the gameplay is decent, and the story is engrossing; however, it just doesn't feel like a CoH game.It feels almost as if SEGA came in and waved their magic wand and made the game too simple to actually enjoy. There are fewer units than the original making the gameplay a little stale. A few bells and whistles that actually hinder the playability.And don't get me started on the dlc: commanders, skins and faceplates...However, the map community and Steam workshop add a tremendous amount of replayability for this title.I was on the fence about this game, however, I probably wouldn't recommend this title unless you are a hardcore RTS fan and enjoy strategy games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												I was looking for a multiplayer RTS that had no resources gathering but still kept strategic and tactical depths. CoH2 ticks all the boxes, with added brilliant graphics and audio to create one intense, immersive experience. Instead of resource gathering you have to capture certain territory points that when held give you the resources you need, such as manpower, munitions or fuel. You are then able to use these resource points to make building upgrades which then allow you to get better units or to upgrade your current units with special abilities. It’s very close to a MOBA actually, but with far more complexity.Concerning the campaign parts, it’s okay, but the game really shines in multiplayer, which by playing the campaigns helps you improve your multiplayer skills. The only negatives I can say about the game is that the tutorial should be better, especially to help people that are more interested in just playing multiplayer, and I almost stopped playing because of not quite knowing how it all worked. Also its mini tactical map, which is used consistently, greatly needs improvement, sometimes being very difficult to see where your units are. The larger tactical map is not practical to use so the mini map is mostly relied on and therefore needs to be clearer.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Good for scratching that realistic-RTS itch, but falls dreadfully short on balance (changes per patch) and competitive play. No ladder player what-so-ever. Limited matchmaking that throws you in with first-available opponents - and AOL-age lobby support.Pay to win online play: $1.99-4.99 for premium Commanders that completely outshine their default commanders or exploit over powered mechanics (mostly an issue with OKW/USF, but definitely apparent for Sov/Wer).Core gameplay is mostly minor improvements on the winning formula from CoH 1, but now wrapped and infused with micotransactions and DLC.Even if you only buy the base game/armies - you'll enjoy the game, but you'll quickly hate the developers/publishers for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥izing a game with so much potential to be the definitive WW2-RTS, as the shortcuts for the sake of profit is literally evident in almost every element of the game.You'll hate yourself for enjoying this game because of what it means for modern gaming development/DLC.

Posted: October 31, 2014
												Ive spent a few hours on this game :)I can tell you the game itself WAS intense and exciting. Plenty of action across the battlefield.The problem is with the realism and balance. If you are like me and ONLY want to PVP then I would say skip this game. Look around for something else or wait for the next big RTS to come out. The biggest problem is that there is NOTHING similar to this game anywhere. I mean, sure you can go back to COH1 but going to an older game is just lame. Unfortunately we WW2 strategy junkies are stuck with this unbalanced saga that is COH2.Anyway, if you decide to buy this game heres the score...The devs seem to bend over backwards and give in to the crying masses, you know the ones that yell "OP" about everything instead of sticking to realistic guidelines.So, the game has changed into blob vs blob. Basically you build a large mass of troops, tanks, guns etc and put a big square around them and charge at another large mass (blob) of troops tanks and guns. the counters for the blob were recently all but removed so unless your blob is the biggest you lose. Simple... So work out which army can build the biggest blob first and stick with them :) You will win everytime.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												I like RTS games.  I also like WW2 themed games.  So believe me when I say that I want to like this game.  It does a few things well.  The overall level of detail in the maps, units is good.  There are plenty of upgrade, customization options out there to help players develop their own strategies, tactics.  It has all of the basic elements of a winner.    However...  The A.I and unit path finding in this game are both awful.  Infuriatingly...unforgivably awful.  I appreciate the fact that the unit I.A can't be TOO effective, otherwise the game is just too easy.  But your units in this game totally inept.   - Infantry units will just stand around and get shelled to death unless you micromanage them.  They won't attempt to avoid explosions, fire...or make use of available cover.  They'll just die.   - Vehicles?  Utterly useless.   Don't even think of moving more than two of them at a time.  They'll run amok, cutting each other off, and colliding randomly all the way to their destination.  They'll struggle around every single terrain obstacle, taking the worst conceivable path unless you painstakingly direct them around every rock and tree.  This takes pretty much as much time as it would if you had just let them just traverse the entire map.  Some times they'll just do what they want despite all of your furious clicking and keyboard mashing.  They'll roll right over friendly defensive structures, destroying them and scattering your (previously well protected) infantry onto open ground.  They'll also drive straight onto your own tank traps if you let them.  I've seriously watched tanks and artillery rotate 300 degrees in the wrong direction to face a target, then fail to engage.  they'll just sit there.  Your infantry units will cohabitate with opposing units, often moving into point blank range before engaging.  The proximity/collision detection in this game is totally broken.     I've played the campaigns in this game, as well as Ardennes Assault (in the hope that they had addresses these issues)  My verdict:  There's no way in hell that I'll ever pay another dime to this franchise until they start fixing this garbage.  Playing this game starts to feel like a chore after a while because you'll spend half of your time making sure that your units aren't spinning around in a corner somewhere.  After 3 stand alone releases, and a mountain of DLC, there's just no excuse for such shoddy gameplay.  FAIL

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Great concept, good mechanics, HORRENDOUS balance and pay 2 win nonsense. The German side is simply out matched in every regard. Their basic grenider infantry unit is only good at long range and when stationary, so the allies have to simply just charge at them to knock them out. The Greniders do not get sub machine guns, yet the allied squads all do. In addition, the German squads have 4 men to the allied 6... and cannot fire grenades until you advance your battle phase to level 1... while the allies can upgrade to grenades immediately... pay 2 win allows allied players to get hordes of veteran riflemen RIGHT OFF THE BAT and just swarm your under powered trash infantry, even if they have MG42 support. One would think that the German tanks would be better then right? WRONG  The allies get more tanks, and for some strange reason a Sherman tank in the game is better then basically every German tank, despite the fact in real life they were easy to knock out, you will routinely see a Sherman shrugging off tank rounds like it is a Tiger tank... yet it is not. The T-34 is equally OP, but at least they have an historical excuse for that. I cannot tell you how many times I have tried to adjust my startegy as Germans and time and time again you just get swamp with masses of infantry and tanks. I finally quit after a match in which we destroyed twice as many enemy units as they did, but still lost because they easily replace everything, have pay 2 win veteran infantry, and pay 2 win massive sherman easy 8 tank destroyers. DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME AND MONEY ON THIS UNBALANCED TRASH

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												The game is good for exciting, fast skirmishes. About it. The buildup and speed runs slightly faster than that of CoH1. However the game is also far more frustrating. Ever watched as a squad member lagged behind halfway across the map because he couldn't get around a set of sandbags? Or a squad that literally can't see anything because of a couple of trees around it due to "truesight"? Or a heavy flak gun become half useless because of two trees it can't destroy after two dozen shells? Thanks Relic for spending all your time on DLCs and not fixing basic gameplay problems.I don't have as much issue with the DLC commanders as most people. Even some of the basic commanders are great to use. The part that's annoying is that you can't use some of the cooler units in the game without paying for certain commander DLCs, nor can you access certain counter-strategies without them. For example if you enjoy playing Soviets but wish you had T-34-85s to counter the standard german Panzer V Panther... well too bad, go grab a DLC.The campaign plays like Hollywood propaganda from the Cold War. Where are the great tank battles of Kursk? The marshland penetrations of Bagration? The high altitude combat in the Caucausus, especially the highest elevation fight at Refuge of the 11? The assault on the Sevastapol coastal batteries? Even the climatic bridge meeting between the two pincers of Stalingrad? Nah. Forgot all these cool mission ideas. Let's just focus on making the brainless slavic horde look at bad as possible against their heroic Wehrmacht foes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Has the frame work of a decent game, building of the first, however seems to have taken several steps in a bad diretion. The campaign is fairly standard for games set in the era, but plays out fairly well, unit response times and where they choose to go can be frustrating, moving to stand infront of the cover you sent them too if you dont carefully move your cursor around to see where they will all go forr example. But these arn't game breaking issues really.The main issues come when you have completed the campaign, skirrmish maps are very restrictive, you are limited to a low population cap with no options of changing and your choice of units feels very small, while there are some standard units for both sides some of the more fun ones and any of the abilities are locked to commanders, so you're unlikely to be able to field a selection of your favorite units at the same time. There are also many commanders that cost money, at a pretty high price tag for what you get. Not to mention units like the tiger or some artillerey pieces come with their own high population cost (nearly a 1/4 of your total). Along with commanders, colour patterns for your tanks and faceplates you can also pay for added misson packs. Don't. Most of these missions aren't even missons they are lazy attempts, basically a skirmish game you could set up yourself. while therer are one or two actual scripted missons like the campaign they are no where near worth the price tag to unlock. Over all I'd give this game a 3/10, which makes me sad given afew changes and less DLC it would have been in my top games to play.

												This is a horrible game! COH2 sucks so bad! The gameplay is horrible and it is very annoying. Your troops are so weak that even though you outnumber the enemies or have veterancy, they still end up dying. WTH?! There is also lack of resources. You barely have enough to buy more men or vehicles. The generals in the game are also annoying. Especially when your units die all the time, generals always tell you they die. General obvious. The game wants to be realistic but it's horrible. It ended up being unbalanced and troops always end up dying so easily. The beta was a bit more realistic and plays better at times. Though the beta is still horrible too. This is regardless of MP or SP. The good things are the graphics, improved some gameplay elements, and that's about it. The whole game revolves around the annoying and horrible gameplay. COH1 was so much better and more fun. This game is annoying and not very fun. Money wasted on this poor game. Nothing against Russians but in the game, they should be more powerful or balanced. I'll rather settle for Germans, which seems to retain traditional gameplay and a bit more powerful and more resources. Generally, this game is mediocore and annoying. I will be playing more of COH1. COH1 over COH2 any day. 7/10.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Company of Heroes 2 sees new content added to the CoH series as well as a few differences in gameplay that are good ideas, but overall everything could have been improved upon. For starters the field of view they implimented where soldiers cannot see over headges taller than them or through buildings, can create the oppertunitity for a great sneak attack and defence in a game. HOWEVER the same field of view does NOT apply for TANKS and other vehichles.... Umm hello? do these tank crews see through armour plaiting? why are there vision slits in the game if the crew cannot see only out of those vision slits unless the commander "turns out" in the tank. There are more examples of great ideas/changes that could have been better or just failed completley but I would be here all day writting this review, but I am not going to because chances are you wouldnt read the whole thing anyway.DL MOTHER F***ING C|_|_____________| DLCs such as ardennes assault (which should have been with the american DLC) as well as commanders/skin packs/all that other pay ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that should have been in the game to start with. MONEY MAKING TO THE MAX!!!!!!!!!!!!! I am supprised the dont make you pay for a DLC that lets you implement the damn workshop into the game (fingers crossed they arnt working on that)As  diehard fan of CoH since I played the original back on my old PC I would really love to see this game series continue. BUT with more considerations for the fans. To make a game that we will love the way they used to be made. WITH ALL THE CONTENT IN THE GAME. I would love to give this a thumbsup because I do love to play this game but it is for that reason alone that I cannot.Please think about this for CoH 3.... if there is going to be one...p.s I do not own a steam version of CoH 1 which is why I do not have it in my steam library, however, I do have the original boxed version and have played numerous hours of the game (honestly I played so much I couldnt tell you how many hours I played [thats what steam is for ;) ] From online to single player I played the **** outta that game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												Before reading just so you know I tend to prefer playing RTS games with friends cooperatively than against anyone so I play skirms against bots since I don't find being competative very fun. So my opinion is limited with respect to online play against others.Short Version:    Pros:Still a tactical war game.Includes hazards from the environment.Fog of war is only revealed by line of sight.    Cons:Way to much of it is DLC, and DLC is too expensive for what little you get.Coop Scenarios are no different from skirmishes with restrictions.Units just don't feel as useful as they were in other games.I just don't find it as fun.Before someone thinks it I definitely don't claim to be at all good at this game, or at any RTS really, but I find it pretty easy to find a game that I'm mediocre or even♥♥♥♥♥♥at fun to play and this just isn't one of them. To be honest if a friend didn't buy this for me I doubt I'd have managed to find enough good in it to own it right now.Compared to the first game I think this one improved very little. The ability to have your sight blocked by buildings, being limited by the cold weather, and being able to shoot the ice to sink tanks as a means of clearing them out quickly are nice additions but that's about it for me. The new units just don't feel as versatile or as useful as they were in the first one. Also I personally find the bulletins next to useless since something you'd really one like recharge on the katyusha since it can only attack with it's ability or more accuracy for AT guns seem unavailible and even if they are they're usually 2-4% difference which is hard to notice unless you use them excessively in your strategy.The most frustrating part of this game is everything they added they seemed to have flipped a coin to see if they should put a select of a purchase button under it. So much of the content is actually DLC, there are loads more commanders to choose from but 80% of them are gated. And the thing is it's not even reasonably priced, single commanders for $5 each, useless cosmetic stuff like tank skins or faceplates for your nametag are $3 or so. As of writing this half the scenarios in the theatre of war are bought seperately.For those who occationally play bots with friends or coop scenerios I'll say this. The coop scenerios are a joke, they are just a pre set skirmish with some dialog and restrictions tossed in (You can't use units that weren't availible before the that time period). If you're really lucky they'll have a mechanic added such as only one of the two can use tanks while the other can only use infantry, or you get extra resources if you're outcapped but that's pretty rare. Largely they're just skirmishes where the army and map is already set out. Also the bots difficulty scales weirdly in my opinion. One difficulty they'll feel like they don't do anything but the one above it will have them set on horde mode somehow sending constant streams at you.Lastly the RNG in this game kicks the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me. This game like the first one has a general radius where your shots land, so shooting a tank with a tank will be easy but it may miss smaller targets like infantry, but this doesn't seem to apply to bots as much. I've had them killed my snipers multiple times with a single shot with an AT gun (actually seems to happen everytime i try to snipe off the AT crew), my scout cars machine guns will be hitting nearby butterflys while theirs so much as looks at my infantry and half my unit is dead. Additionally I'll stick my units in good cover and still lose a fire fight against an enemy unit of the same type standing in the open. A single enemy rocket barrage clears out my garrisons. Mortar troops managing to nearly destroy an entire unit with perfect shots. etc...

												This game started off with real promise.. it seemed like it was going to be a great sequel. Then patch after patch it fell so short of its predecessor. This game is a real time strategy that is trying to be league of legends. Focused around a small number of small sized units engaging in skirmishes. World War II was anything but small skirmishes, especially along the eastern front where millions of soldiers and armored units engaged in all out war. This game is nothing but a money trap, and shows just how much this company has sold out. I would recommend buying company of heroes 1 over this game anyday. CoH1 is an outstanding game to this day, and is leaps and bounds better than this piece of garbage even today.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												Dear Would-be-Player, It is possible that this incarnation of Company of Heroes will work on your computer without crashing repeatedly and severely as it has on mine. It is possible that you will get great enjoyment out of the relatively few components of the game that you get when you lay your money down for the game, for the relatively few minutes or maybe even a few hours before it either hangs or crashes your computer. You may be happy to keep paying for DLC's. Perhaps your computer is the latest and greatest model, one that can handle the idiosyncracies of this game design instead of a gaming laptop computer that was the envy of many players just a few years ago, with its ATI mobility Radeon HD4670 that easily coped with other demanding titles. But not this one, not CoH2. Perhaps the game won't potentially damage your computer. Maybe you are a mellow soul who does not feel troubled to be told that "Your remedy for dissatisfaction with the game software or any products, content, or other information made available by or through SEGA, is to stop using the software." I wish you luck, and the hours of enjoyment I have not had the pleasure of. I wish you the (relatively) innocent war-game player satisfaction - while I try to refrain from wishing afflictions such as herpes simplex, STD's, lice, excema and hairy warts on those who write such self serving EULA "agreements" and design games like these in such a shoddy and money grubbing manner. I shall uninstall it from this computer and try it on my newer work computer and hope it doesn't cause that to also crash repeatedly. If it does so, my wishes upon the Sega game designers  are sure to be rather more extravagant! All I will say right now is that I do not feel my dissatisfaction to be in any way remedied ......

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Could not finish the tutorial owing to a bug. Asked me to left-click to start artillery fire, but that didn't do anything. The camera was locked and the tutorial was scripted so I couldn't do anything until I finished that part. Appears to be decent RTS where you control a small number of units which gain veterancy and can pick up upgrades. Beginning of the game appears heavily scripted, with not much in terms of interesting alternate ways of defeating the enemy. Expect the community maps and other maps further along allows more interesting strategy options. Like the cover system so far, with little dots telling you where your troops will end up. Unfortunately, the send-to-cover system appears to be agnostic to the direction of incoming fire. Half your troops on the wrong side of cover quite often unless you keep looking for the one cover option where all are on the right side.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												I wanted to love this game. Being a huge fan of the original Company of Heroes the idea of sequel with new game mechanics and units made my heart flutter. I watched videos with the developers talking about ice shelves being destructible, having to build fires so you troops don't freeze to death, adding a fog of war with snowstorms and all sorts of really amazing stuff.What they didn't tell you though, was that they were going to dumb down the game to lowest common denominator. In the original your play style could be complimented by each DISTINCTIVE army. Don't like to muddle around with different unit types and blast the enemy constantly? Cool, we've got some Panzer Elite for you. Are you a turtle and want to play a Sim-City RTS? Great, got a Brit army right over here. CoH2 plays the same no matter who you play as and you are forced to play offensively. Defenses are ineffective and troops between armies indistinguishable, more or less.  The icing on the cake of disappointment comes with the DLC. If you want a little variety in your dull game it can be purchased one small piece at a time. Way to milk a mediocre product for more money that I should have never spent in the first place.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												My initial review was after about 20 hours of gameplay and I have since decided to change that review now that I have near 100 hours logged.  From the start this game falls flat on its face due to the outrageous price and loaded DLC that Relic claims is for "continued support".  What a load of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  Never until this decade has DLC gotten so out of control.  Companies out there that make games with no DLC charge less for some of their games and patch them for years afterwards.  But, enough about the horrendous business model that has lost my money and more about the game.     Company of Heroes 2 takes what the 1st one did and makes it bland.  No longer are you able to approach a situation from multiple vectors of possibilities and are now forced to be aggressive.  Trench wars, defensive positions, and the general concept of holding a point and inching forward no longer exists unless you build a custom map with a specific choke point that is designed to do just this.  Commanders do very little other than offer a few units that you can't build or offer some weapons you normally wouldn't get.  Don't think for an instant this is a direct equivalent to the doctrines in the first CoH because it isn't, not even by a long shot.  T-34 85s are called in units and not build versus the 76s that are built.  Tigers are called in and not built.  Population is capped at 100 unless you manually change it in the map editor.  No V1 rockets or other cool special abilities like calling in a King Tiger, JagdPanther, Pershing Tank, etc.  Just a few fragmentation bombing runs, and plane strafes with some other abilities like camo, tank smoke, etc.     The game does do well graphically, I will give it that but I do not believe that is anyhwere near sufficient to call this a second game.  Sounds are just as realisitic as they were in the first one but pathfinding seems to never have been improved.  I guess they wanted to focus on vaulting over sandbags and walls instead of fixing critical issues from a game that suffered the same issues 7 years ago.  Buying barbed wire cutters for engineers because they don't come with them, you know....cause engineers don't work in situations like that...or something.....       I really hate to fill a review with constant negatives so I will put a few of the things that this games does manage to do well.  First, I like the concept that Germans and Russians can play on the same team.  This slightly alters the single strategy concept that this game has embedded into its core.  I also like that you can repair bridges if they are partially damaged instead of waiting until it is completely gone.  Another great aspect of this game is that the physics have been improved.  Tanks feel more like tanks as they rock when they shoot and get hit and actually have a reverse button so you arn't spam clicking or queueing your tank backwards like you had to in the first installment.  Finally, capping points by standing near them is great.  I no longer have to make sure my units are capping, all I have to do is get them within the area of effect for it to begin capturing.     Unfortunately, that is really all I can think of that makes the game look decent.  All of the improper balancing due to a new and whiny community is holding this game back.  I wish Relic would just balance the game as they see fit, it worked great for the first installment.  Gamers are entirely to whiny and shed tears when something doesn't go their way, but then again that is the way most my country is.  People will whine because they can't play, don't understand a concept, or simply just don't get their way but a game like this shouldn't be altered because of those reasons.  Single minded strategy, a massively cheating AI, and horrendous balancing with laregely missing content make this game a no purchase unless you are either bored or get it during a massive sale, and by massive I mean 75% or more.  Do yourself a favor, don't get burned.

												DO NOT BUY. I have hundreds of hours of playtime in this game and I can tell you that it`s not worth it. The game is terribly optimized, terribly balanced (snipers are incredibly OP and there is no counter to them) and the business model is the final nail in the coffin. Since they try to milk the cash through the sale of additional commanders (who possess additional units and abilities), the core (non-commander) unit pool is pretty poor and the game lacks strategic depth.The only reason that could justify the purchase is the fact that there are no good RTS games nowadays. So if you are an RTS fan and you need your fix there aren`t many options and I wouldn`t blame you. You`ve been warned though.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												As a Company of Heroes "veteran", I understand how the game is played or should be played. I call myself a "veteran" not because I am fantastically amazing at the game because I'm not. I call myself a veteran because I have played almost everything Company of Heroes related. I played Company of Heroes 1, Company of Heroes Online (when it was still active), all of the expansions to Company of Heroes 1, and Company of Heroes 2. I have yet to get the Ardennes Assault DLC though I do have the Western Front Armies pack. From my experinces on Company of Heroes 1, the game can get very competitive. But it's not a right competitiveness. The competition someone will face in Company of Heroes Multiplayer is one that will only irritate you and make you want to sling your computer out of the window from the frustration that will follow. Why so much irritation and frustration you may ask? It isn't because that people play right and fair. It's because nobody does anything original. Every match you enter, you will be facing someone who will more than likely do one of three things. 1: They wil spam non-stop throughout the entirity of the match. 2: They will spam Commander abilities in your base non-stop. 3: They will do both of the above. Now these "tactics" that I have listed are moer relevant to Company of Heroes 2 that Company of Heroes 1 because Commander abilities in Company of Heroes 1 were much more limited and much more expensive and harder to spam due to map design for resources. But as a personal experience from a Company of Heroes 2 match, I counted that my opponent used the IL-2 Gun Strafe a grand total of 28 times. But if someone were to buy this game, I would suggest they only fight AI battles and play the campaign. Anyone who does that will have more fun than anyone who attempts to fight others in multiplayer. In my personal opinion, the campaign for Company of Heroes 2 was a great story but some of the missions were ridiculously hard because of what you are given to fight with. Overall, I would rate the campaign a 7/10 just because of the sheer impossibility of some missions. Compared to Company of Heroes 1's campaign, Company of Heroes 2's campaign added more of a personal face to a different side of the war. Company of Heroes 1's campaign gave a great history of how World War II unfolded on the Western Front. Now multiplayer, I would rate about 4/10 just because of the people who play on it. AI battles would be a 9/10 just because the AI progressively advances the longer the match lasts. The overall game of Company of Heroes 2, however, I would rate a 6/10 with everything mixed together. Though multiplayer on Company of Heroes 2 has made me more angry than Call of Duty (which enrages me nearly every time I play) at times, the game is a definate improvement over Company of Heroes 1 in game-play effects and balancing and new play styles that came from the addition of True Sight. But all in all, this game is only for someone who enjoys playing with friends because playing with strangers is out of the question.

												Greetings,    I have been playing company of heros 2 for several months now, Recently reaching my 500 hour mark. The game is fantastic if you enjoy strategy and rts games in general. While many people are upset with balance issues etc. i feel that the game for the most part balanced. Every side has a over powered unit or 2 but every unit has a weakness. It is all about countering.  The games graphics are beautiful and the little details that are hidden are nice. The campaign was fun and kept me busy for a bit. The dlc might seem greedy on relics part but i own all of them and have enjoyed it all. I highly recommend this game. Would also recommend some blood pressure meds to go with it.

												DO NOT BUY. I have hundreds of hours of playtime in this game and I can tell you that it`s not worth it. The game is terribly optimized, terribly balanced (snipers are incredibly OP and there is no counter to them) and the business model is the final nail in the coffin. Since they try to milk the cash through the sale of additional commanders (who possess additional units and abilities), the core (non-commander) unit pool is pretty poor and the game lacks strategic depth.The only reason that could justify the purchase is the fact that there are no good RTS games nowadays. So if you are an RTS fan and you need your fix there aren`t many options and I wouldn`t blame you. You`ve been warned though.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Could not finish the tutorial owing to a bug. Asked me to left-click to start artillery fire, but that didn't do anything. The camera was locked and the tutorial was scripted so I couldn't do anything until I finished that part. Appears to be decent RTS where you control a small number of units which gain veterancy and can pick up upgrades. Beginning of the game appears heavily scripted, with not much in terms of interesting alternate ways of defeating the enemy. Expect the community maps and other maps further along allows more interesting strategy options. Like the cover system so far, with little dots telling you where your troops will end up. Unfortunately, the send-to-cover system appears to be agnostic to the direction of incoming fire. Half your troops on the wrong side of cover quite often unless you keep looking for the one cover option where all are on the right side.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												I was waiting for this game for a long time. Compared to the first CoH, it is a terrible game. It is not terrible because it is not the same, but it is terrible because it feels like the game was not made with much thought. There are so many DLCs, and the tech trees for each commander seems so limited, so much of variations on the same theme. The best commanders are only available as "pay to win". The matchmaking system is HORRIBLE. Why not just let me screen for games on a browser and join them? Why only let me select one choice for a match, when I may be open to several different types of games? Matchmaking systems should always be optional.The way they changed infantry and vehicle balance also made the game feel much more vehicle focused. Most infantry, even some antitank infantry, don't stand a chance against tanks. They just drop like flies, even under cover (though it might also be the hacking AI). The AT guns are also clunky and require just as much pop cap as a small or medium tank. The AI cheats like crazy for comp stomp games. Example: you cannot field any snipers because they will be killed magically by magic mortars and other freak shots. You can only play certain tactics against the AI, as all the other normal tactics will fail to their horrible hacks (worst than the first one, not even fun, why not put some more thought into AI?). Playing against the computer becomes an exercise in patience, and it is not fun.Even though I spent a pretty penny on this game and a few DLCs, and I really wanted to like this game, I have gone back to CoH original. Good luck to everyone else.

												The game itself seems like a fun concept with good graphics and realism but:Most of the game is locked out with purchase/DLC options including all single player campaign content.The tutorial is almost useless.There is apparently no map scrolling and clicking on the minimap to select a different area all the time is tedious and not accurate enough.I played through the single and small tutorial mission and enjoyed the game so far though all it teaches you to do is to move and select an enemy unit to fire on.The next screen was filled with Buy Now! Buy Now! Buy Now! Buy Now! missions... so I clicked to play the single player campaigns and only got two options. I tried Ardennes Assault and saw Purchase... So I went back and clicked the Russian one and got - yes, you guessed it - Purchase... So there's no single player campaign missions included with the game? Strike one and major fail in my opinion.I tried Theatre of War - Battles, Challenges and Co-Op Scenarios - which had 4 options. All of which had Purchase instead of start mission or something useful. Strike two.The only thing left was Online & Skirmish - Automatch vs Players seemed to work, but I had no interest in playing against other players when I really had no idea what I was doing yet. Three strikes.I tried Automatch vs AI but again it was multiplayer vs AI and I wanted to play solo.In my fifth and final attempt to actually play this game I tried Create Custom Game and I was finally able to create a game which had me vs an AI player. I had no idea what I was doing and failed quickly and horribly. I'm done.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												SPOILER: I'm going to give this game a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ review. Keep on reading if you want to know why.I dislike this game strongly not on account of being Russian and have some game writer who have seen one Hollywood movie take a dump on the history of my country. Nor for displaying the Soviet Red Army as a horde of ruthless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ animals who were killed casually by friend and foe ("Enemy At The Gates", anyone?), hinting at the assumption that the only reason Soviets were able to kick the Germans out of the Soviet Union was because the latter ran out of bullets. Also, Winter. Then again, if you want to learn history, play the Civ series.I dislike this game because of the following: dumb and poorly written dialogues, with cliché lines and stories taken from thin air. I dislike this game because of the language, with a mix of Russian obscenities and ridiculous accents (like "Red Heat"); either you go all the way and do dialogues in Russian and with English narration, or do it like in Red Alert-series. This language/accent mixture makes me think of parodies on Soviet armed forces from various comedies, action movies from the 80's and 90's and games like "Red Alert", which negates this game's attempt at being a serious and challenging RTS about a serious and grave war. Unlike CoH, where dialgoues, speech and general use of spoken langauges were well executed, which gave CoH the perfect mood the creators intended for it, I don't feel passionate about anything or anyone in CoH2, mostly due to the fact that the characters make me think of cartoonish characters.As for the gameplay aspect, well, the perfectly imbalanced forces on both sides are...imbalanced. On one hand you have the OP German forces, on the other - Soviet morons who die like flies from everything, including breathing, apparently. Heck, in CoH I often managed to keep at least one squad alive throughout an entire mission; here, you are lucky if your Soviet squad lives the first 5 minutes of a battle! Even 'elite' forces drop dead for no reason! Which sucks bum on missions where you have to rely on special tactics squads. With this in mind, the intense action and fast pace of the game are more of an annoyance, rather than a pleasant challenge. The Winter missions were an interesting aspect, but, again, with your forces' life expectancy equal to that of a banana in a family of monkeys, restarting these missions from last save time and time again became tedious very fast.As for the performance, I don't get why this game needs more than 15GB of free space; the graphics haven't improved, the cinematics are crappy; what the heck does it use this space for?!In conclusion, I only bought this game because it was on Relic sale on the weekly Humble Bundle, and I won't play it again. I don't care for the graphics, I wanted the story. What I got was crappy dialogues, badly written plot and story, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mission, irritating gameplay mechanics, and general annoyance every time someone said something (yes, I'm obsessed with language, but then, I'm also a linguist, so shovel it, OK?). This game takes a huge dump on CoH-series. Mods is this game's only hope. What the clucking bell were SEGA and Relic thinking when they released a sequel this bad? And I am not the only one to give the game a scolding review, far from it.Buy it if you have too much empty space on your hard drive or want to revisit the Red Alert universe. Otherwise, you'd be better off with other Relic games.

												I think I just bought something that should be a free to play. There are adds everywhere for skinpacks, map packs, mini campaigns, etc. This is why so many people are against DLC. Games like this abuse the DLC system beyond belief. You basically pay for things that should already be in the game, like maps, missions, co-op things, skins, and profile custimization. Its also way overpriced for the vanilla game in general, and I bought this game on sale for less then $20. The $20 I had to spend to just play the very basic piece of this game would be like paying to play a "free to play" styled game. I seriously want my money back for this one. Shame considering you'd expect more from this game series... really disapointed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												The original company of heroes series were for a long time my favourite games ever. Somehow all of the charm, smooth play, great feel and depth of CoH has been completely lost. If you enjoyed the first game and it's expansions, stick with them. This is, very sadly, not a good sequel.Map design and pathing are sub-par, the upgrade system unexplained and somewhat un-needed, the in game units are less defined, the graphics are no big upgrade, the AI is completely broken (There is no way that anyone but a CoH veteran will beat the computer on 'standard' difficulty in skirmishes) and there is just a generally disjointed, unfinished, un-polished air to everything. The total opposite to how CoH 1 felt, which is really confusing considering how similar they are.3/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												This game has a lot of improvements made from the previous COH in the series, especially the vehicle combat system. The strategy in the game has made it harder to use a single unit-class, forcing players to diversify more and expand their own playstyles. Some don't like it, but I actually welcome the change!I played through the Campaign, and while it was good for a stand-alone story, I can understand how Russians may take offense at it. I read some reviews saying it was a pro-Nazi perspective, making the Russians seem like the bad guys, but when I played it, I didn't get that feeling. The story seemed to have elements of truth in it, but pieces were exaggerated for the sake of cinematography in the game.The best part, however, is the multiplayer. The automatch system was an unusual change from vanilla COH's server-list selection, but after you get familiar with it, it's extremely helpful for getting the game you want to play online. Interestingly, when you start your auotmatch, it shows the percentage of German commanders and Soviet commanders also looking for games. I love this, because if I choose Soviets, but there's already a lot, I'll switch to German in a heartbeat to get into a game faster.I feel the balancing in the game is really good! I don't feel like one side is over-powered in any way, but they do have different playstyles that I love to utilize.Overall, I would certainly recommend this game to a friend. It's fun to play, it's beautiful to watch, and the combat is exhilirating. Worth every penny  I spent!

												This game goes against what historians say about what happened in the eastern front and gets it all wrong in the story line, everyting from Order 227 to Scorched Earth policy is potrayed wrongly but it's made by relic and relic is a canadian company. First off Order 227 is potrayed as this order that if soviet troops retreat they will be shot as soon as they make it back to their commander, in real life they would have been shot but only for desertion and they would have been given a warning before they were shot. Second the scorched earth policy is potrayed as an order given by stalin to destroy all buildings and material before retreating from your position, in real life building that wern't occupied by civillians were desginated for destruction and the material was to be used to slow the enemy advance. The only good thing about this game is the gameplay in multiplayer mode. And after this games failed launch were it recived heavy criticisem from eastern europeans, relic soon came out with the western front allies which really is just a new version of company of heroes one. what keeps this game going is the mountain of Steam workshop items that can be downloaded a good amount are good some are bad but there is maps, tuning packs that improve game play or give you diffrent/extra units and win condition where it modifies how you win a match.In world war 2 one shot from a ISU-152 was able to destroy a panzer 4 with one shot in this game a panzer 4's main 75mm gun with standard shell can rip apart a ISU when hitting the frontal armor when a the front armor of a ISU was able to defeat the 75mm shell.The AI DO NOT pay resource cost by this I mean if a machine gun and crew cost 300 man power the AI pays nothing I've been in matchs against AI that 1 minute into the match they have 4 MG's and like 10 squads of infantry where I have like 4 squads and 1 MG and I have spent all man power on these units and you could push the enemy back to their base and they have no resource income but they will still field a bunch of infantry and spawn a heavy tank.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Has the frame work of a decent game, building of the first, however seems to have taken several steps in a bad diretion. The campaign is fairly standard for games set in the era, but plays out fairly well, unit response times and where they choose to go can be frustrating, moving to stand infront of the cover you sent them too if you dont carefully move your cursor around to see where they will all go forr example. But these arn't game breaking issues really.The main issues come when you have completed the campaign, skirrmish maps are very restrictive, you are limited to a low population cap with no options of changing and your choice of units feels very small, while there are some standard units for both sides some of the more fun ones and any of the abilities are locked to commanders, so you're unlikely to be able to field a selection of your favorite units at the same time. There are also many commanders that cost money, at a pretty high price tag for what you get. Not to mention units like the tiger or some artillerey pieces come with their own high population cost (nearly a 1/4 of your total). Along with commanders, colour patterns for your tanks and faceplates you can also pay for added misson packs. Don't. Most of these missions aren't even missons they are lazy attempts, basically a skirmish game you could set up yourself. while therer are one or two actual scripted missons like the campaign they are no where near worth the price tag to unlock. Over all I'd give this game a 3/10, which makes me sad given afew changes and less DLC it would have been in my top games to play.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												This is a good game I will admit that but there are several major issues that drag the game.It has great potential but it has holes that scream to be filled with DLC (and some already have)The game is focused around WW2 during the German invasion of Russia it offers a 14 mission long campaign a skirmish mode against the AI and an active multiplayer base there are 2 sides (unless u buy DLC which adds 2 more:The Oberkommando Wehrmacht and United States Forces)the German Wehrmacht and the USSR each having different strengths and weaknesses the campaign is based around a a Soviet Liutenant named Abraham Ivaskovych (or something along those lines) who was sent to a Gulag for apparent crimes against the state (I won't spoil the story not that there is much to spoil just in case u do buy the game) he is visited by his former officer Churkin (I forget his first name) it brings you from the beginning of the invasion (u play as the USSR in the campaign) to the siege of Berlin the campaign is hard which  is good (I completed it on captain which is basicly normal) the characters however are boring and I couldn't really care less about them The combat is enjoyable and is satisfying when u destroy an enemy unit or an enemy tank u will choose in multiplayer/skirmish a commander during the game which gives u abilities and bonuses these are unlocked by levelling up every time u level up u MIGHT earn ''warspoils'' which are either upgrades eg.one might give ur Grenadiers/Conscripts 3% more accuracy they are very small bonuses and I pay little attention to them as the differences they enact are quite minor the game is a base builder RTS the USSR and Wehrmacht are very different which is obviously good the game unfortunately however does not have good balance the Wehrmacht is clearly better than the USSR and with the DLC the OKW is very superior compared to the USF and Conscripts are too good these are some balancing issuesPros:Enjoyable combatGood resources systemBoth sides are fun to playHard campaignLong campaign Good AIFun multiplayer Cons:Bad balancing (The German factions are superior to the Allied ones and the US are more of a weakness than a strength)Unit strengths are historically innacurate Uninteresting campaign charactersLack of unit variety Many areas that are clearly going to be filled with DLC Tanks are too expensiveOverall I would not reccomend this because even though there are more pros than cons the some cons are too major to be forgiven if u are looking for a great WW2 Base building RTS with a good campaign then I would reccommend the original Company of Heroes it is far superior and I have a positive review for that if u wish to look at it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7
												Company of Heroes 2 is a dynamic Real Time Strategy game based in the european theater of World War 2. At the moment you can play as 5 different factions: the Soviets and the Wehrmacht on the eastern front and on the western front you have the United States Forces, United Kingdom Forces and the Oberkommando West. This game is similar to other RTS games like StarCraft and Age of Empires in the matter that you can build units, construct new base buildings and micro. However this games differs heavily in how resources are collected. Instead of mineral gathers in StarCraft you gain additional resource income from capturing more territory for your team. More territory = more fuel and munitions. Manpower income is all dependant on your army size, larger the army = less income. Munitions in CoH2 is used for numerous upgrades and abilities such as throwing grenades or giving your riflemen BARs and bazookas. You can also use resources for offmap abilities like artillery and flares for vision. Fuel is often the most contested of the resources because the more fuel you have the more frequent you can construct tanks and with higher quality if you wish.CoH2 has 4 different types of PvP game modes, 1v1 2v2 3v3 and 4v4. In my opinion 1v1 is where you see the most intense actions and skill of the highest level. You can see your mistakes when you mess up, and you can see fantastic plays when you outflank your opponet and force retreats.One of the core functions of this game is the "Retreat" function. Giving a squad a "retreat" command allows them to begin returning to your base and at an accelerated rate but once given it cannot be undone. Retreating squads allows you to retain your squad and its veterancy which in turn allows them to reinforce men they've lost and makes them more effective on the field."Cover" in CoH2 is essentially having an object inbetween your forces and your opponets so instead of bullets hitting your men, they hit the object. Different types of cover provide different benefits. No cover provides no bonuses, light cover provides a received accuracy bonus and heavy cover provides both a received accuracy bonus and damage reduction when hit. Negative cover on the other hand which is where your squads are exposed on open terrain such as roads or water provide a received accuracy penalty, meaning your squad will get hit more often. Other types of cover include garrisons which are similar to heavy cover. All these different cover bonuses and penalties have different interactions such as a grenade being thrown into a garrison, or a flamethrower being used against a squad in water. To win a match in CoH2 you need to do 1 of 3 things. Your opponet(s) surrenders the match, you destroy the entire enemy base or you win through Victory Points. Victory Points are additional capture points around the map, usually 3 total to take and hold to drain your opponets of VPs. When your opponet(s) hit 0 VPs the match ends and you have won. Your own VPs hit 0 and you lose.Those are just some of the basic concepts of CoH2 and there is always more to learn and explore with such a dynamic game. Every game is entirely different because in 1 game you may get an early ambush off and wipe a squad quickly and get a major lead. The next game you could have a 50 minute tank slugfest with Tiger 2s and Fireflys.Unfortunatly this game doesn't receive that much love in some areas such as balance and patches due to the smaller community, but the community that exists is very dedicated on playing this game and many players will aid in improvements you can make if you ask.If you're thinking about buying this game I'd highly recommend it, and sales never hurt either. There is quite a few DLC expansions which do add to the game significantly but nearly every Steam sale this game goes on 75% off minimum. Could probably get everything for $20 or less. If you do end up purchasing this game I'd recommend learning from high level players. Youtube holds many shoutcasters who explain details of the game and mechanics. A few of them include: GeneralsGentlemen, tightrope gaming, Helping Hans and The Propagandacast. I watch the first 3 in that list and I can personally say they've all helped me improve my game. Tightrope and Helping Hans both have tutorial videos on their channels which aid greatly in mechanics and tips you can use to up your game.Fair warning though, this game does require significant time to hone skills similar to MOBAs. I believe it is not as severe as that genre on time dedication but it is prominent.Overall its a great game. I can only dream of the game it would be if it had significantly better care. The community is working hard everyday to make it better though so at least one day it'll hopefully be a game worthy of significant remembrance.

They are BS.Game is not pay to win, not at all. Yes, every nation has its own commanders, some you have to earn, some you have to buy, and some you get at the start.The thing i did when i started the game, i tried every nation and just loved absolutely everything about Russians, they fit my style perfectly. So what i did, i then went trough few comanders and found one that i like the most and that i could actually use and have some fun with it. I thought, hmm maybe i shoulde buy it, its only 2.5 euros, should I? YES. And hell yeah i was right, at the momment i played with it i forgot i paid for it, it was so so so much fun.Now, if you want to play with every nation, have every commander and every possible skin, then you will have to pay for it, alot. You can get your commander that you like for 2-3 euros, is not that much money, and you will have alot of fun, and your opponent wont have and advantages over you.If less than 5 euros mean the game is pay to win, then idk what to say.BUT, If you ask me, would i buy the game for its full price, 120 euros ? It's expensive as hell, and IMO, the stupidest thing about this game is not the commanders, its 20 god damn DLCs that you cant play without, and its annoying, but if you can wait for a discount, awesome, you wont regret it, i promise you.I got it for about 20 and maybe 23-24 max with commander and its absolutely worth it.I have to say it again, this game is absolutely phenomenal. 11/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												RTS is probably my weakest genre, so with that in mind, I will mostly just say that I enjoy the game for its detailed and convincing special effects and sound design. It has lots of dramatic gut-wrenching explosions, and there is much fun to be had laying waste to the environment and your opponents alike with heavy mortars and satchel charges. One compelling knock against the game, which I have heard, is the flattening and simplification of the progression system, compared to its predecessor. That is disappointing, because to me, good RTS design is all about that progression, and the complex and interesting ways in which it can lead to a dramatic and often catastrophic crescendo at the end. I think few games do that as well as the classic C&C: Generals.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												Company of Heroes 2 gives an experience that few other games give. Where Men of War gives you a more technical picture of the Second World War Company of Heroes gives a cinematic experience that I have seen in few places. The sound of the engines grinding across the terrain, the dirt being kicked up by the treads and the haze generated by artillery bombardments really helps to immerse the player in the world of the Eastern Front. From a mechanical standpoint this game differs little from its predecessor and remains a solid Relic title. I have little time logged into multiplayer but from what I understand the community is a healthy one. If you want an a WWII title that is pleasing to the eye and can give you a truly immersive experience as far as sound design, set pieces to battle over as either the Wehrmacht or the Red Army (There are other factions available if you feel so inclined to purchase the DLC) this game really is a great place to start before you venture further into the WWII RTS genre.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												Dear Would-be-Player, It is possible that this incarnation of Company of Heroes will work on your computer without crashing repeatedly and severely as it has on mine. It is possible that you will get great enjoyment out of the relatively few components of the game that you get when you lay your money down for the game, for the relatively few minutes or maybe even a few hours before it either hangs or crashes your computer. You may be happy to keep paying for DLC's. Perhaps your computer is the latest and greatest model, one that can handle the idiosyncracies of this game design instead of a gaming laptop computer that was the envy of many players just a few years ago, with its ATI mobility Radeon HD4670 that easily coped with other demanding titles. But not this one, not CoH2. Perhaps the game won't potentially damage your computer. Maybe you are a mellow soul who does not feel troubled to be told that "Your remedy for dissatisfaction with the game software or any products, content, or other information made available by or through SEGA, is to stop using the software." I wish you luck, and the hours of enjoyment I have not had the pleasure of. I wish you the (relatively) innocent war-game player satisfaction - while I try to refrain from wishing afflictions such as herpes simplex, STD's, lice, excema and hairy warts on those who write such self serving EULA "agreements" and design games like these in such a shoddy and money grubbing manner. I shall uninstall it from this computer and try it on my newer work computer and hope it doesn't cause that to also crash repeatedly. If it does so, my wishes upon the Sega game designers  are sure to be rather more extravagant! All I will say right now is that I do not feel my dissatisfaction to be in any way remedied ......

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												I was looking for a multiplayer RTS that had no resources gathering but still kept strategic and tactical depths. CoH2 ticks all the boxes, with added brilliant graphics and audio to create one intense, immersive experience. Instead of resource gathering you have to capture certain territory points that when held give you the resources you need, such as manpower, munitions or fuel. You are then able to use these resource points to make building upgrades which then allow you to get better units or to upgrade your current units with special abilities. It’s very close to a MOBA actually, but with far more complexity.Concerning the campaign parts, it’s okay, but the game really shines in multiplayer, which by playing the campaigns helps you improve your multiplayer skills. The only negatives I can say about the game is that the tutorial should be better, especially to help people that are more interested in just playing multiplayer, and I almost stopped playing because of not quite knowing how it all worked. Also its mini tactical map, which is used consistently, greatly needs improvement, sometimes being very difficult to see where your units are. The larger tactical map is not practical to use so the mini map is mostly relied on and therefore needs to be clearer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												I'll give Company of Heroes a 4/10 because it's not the worst game ever made, I can think of other games that are more deserving of a 0-1/10 - looking at you Big Rigs: Over the Road Racing. However, I (like many other gamers) feel that Company of Heroes 2 just doesn't live up to the expectations of its predecessor. What has happened to the sophisticated commander tree? It has been replaced by a new commander system with no choice, except you can choose 5 different commander 'perks' before a match, then when you get commander points it'll unlock perks automatically (as each perk has a commander point requirement that, once reached, the perk will instantly become available). Okay, but at least CoH 2 has interesting concept art briefs between each mission right? Wrong. Those concept art briefs - which I, personally, loved and associated with the CoH titles - have been replaced by 30 second longish cut scenes between a lieutenant (who you never see or hear from in the missions) that is going to be executed for desertion and his old commander talking about the war - CoH 2 has replaced exciting and interesting character development and artistic cut scenes for a character you'll never see in-game and mediocre between mission cut scenes. There's almost no continuity between missions, in the original CoH you'd get a patriotic and informative brief (so you know what's going on in the grand scale of things), but in CoH 2 it's a case of; a minute cut scene that says "the Germans attacked Russia" and "they get really close to Moscow", from there on it's a case of go there, kill them, we won, fight them - then the level design and gameplay follows this pattern, so what may seem interesting and innovative to start becomes dull and representative in later missions. Yet another CoH 2 mistake is the lack of units, you'll have 2 units that you'll ever really use, your conscripts (infantry) and the T34s (tanks), that's it, you do have snipers (that for some reason only use stealth while they're in cover) and mortar teams etc but what's the point when they'll just get flooded by infantry and tanks? If you want to fight for the Germans, you better go somewhere else, because the singleplayer campaign is all Soviet - you can play as the Germans in multiplayer. Well, you can also play as the Germans in a new feature called 'Theater of War' which, basically, mini-campaigns with about 2 singleplayer missions and tonnes of co-op missions (which is a welcome feature) - but when I realized that my friends weren't prepared to pay £30 for a sub-par sequel, I was left with about 4 hours of German gameplay, max...Well... I think I've said all that I can about Company of Heroes 2. In conclusion, I'm not satisfied with Sega's sequel on what was a milestone in real-time strategy games. It has lost its strategy and has replaced it with numbers. And has many little 'features' that'll drive you mad, like units flashing their player colour when they're clicked on and all your recruited units now start off-map so you have to wait for them to come to you. There seems to be a never ending list of what's wrong with CoH 2, it's like they got the designs and features from the original games and said "these are good, but, scrap them and let's start from fresh without taking any inspiration from the originals". Plus CoH 2, to me, seems to have been Sega-fied.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												My initial review was after about 20 hours of gameplay and I have since decided to change that review now that I have near 100 hours logged.  From the start this game falls flat on its face due to the outrageous price and loaded DLC that Relic claims is for "continued support".  What a load of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  Never until this decade has DLC gotten so out of control.  Companies out there that make games with no DLC charge less for some of their games and patch them for years afterwards.  But, enough about the horrendous business model that has lost my money and more about the game.     Company of Heroes 2 takes what the 1st one did and makes it bland.  No longer are you able to approach a situation from multiple vectors of possibilities and are now forced to be aggressive.  Trench wars, defensive positions, and the general concept of holding a point and inching forward no longer exists unless you build a custom map with a specific choke point that is designed to do just this.  Commanders do very little other than offer a few units that you can't build or offer some weapons you normally wouldn't get.  Don't think for an instant this is a direct equivalent to the doctrines in the first CoH because it isn't, not even by a long shot.  T-34 85s are called in units and not build versus the 76s that are built.  Tigers are called in and not built.  Population is capped at 100 unless you manually change it in the map editor.  No V1 rockets or other cool special abilities like calling in a King Tiger, JagdPanther, Pershing Tank, etc.  Just a few fragmentation bombing runs, and plane strafes with some other abilities like camo, tank smoke, etc.     The game does do well graphically, I will give it that but I do not believe that is anyhwere near sufficient to call this a second game.  Sounds are just as realisitic as they were in the first one but pathfinding seems to never have been improved.  I guess they wanted to focus on vaulting over sandbags and walls instead of fixing critical issues from a game that suffered the same issues 7 years ago.  Buying barbed wire cutters for engineers because they don't come with them, you know....cause engineers don't work in situations like that...or something.....       I really hate to fill a review with constant negatives so I will put a few of the things that this games does manage to do well.  First, I like the concept that Germans and Russians can play on the same team.  This slightly alters the single strategy concept that this game has embedded into its core.  I also like that you can repair bridges if they are partially damaged instead of waiting until it is completely gone.  Another great aspect of this game is that the physics have been improved.  Tanks feel more like tanks as they rock when they shoot and get hit and actually have a reverse button so you arn't spam clicking or queueing your tank backwards like you had to in the first installment.  Finally, capping points by standing near them is great.  I no longer have to make sure my units are capping, all I have to do is get them within the area of effect for it to begin capturing.     Unfortunately, that is really all I can think of that makes the game look decent.  All of the improper balancing due to a new and whiny community is holding this game back.  I wish Relic would just balance the game as they see fit, it worked great for the first installment.  Gamers are entirely to whiny and shed tears when something doesn't go their way, but then again that is the way most my country is.  People will whine because they can't play, don't understand a concept, or simply just don't get their way but a game like this shouldn't be altered because of those reasons.  Single minded strategy, a massively cheating AI, and horrendous balancing with laregely missing content make this game a no purchase unless you are either bored or get it during a massive sale, and by massive I mean 75% or more.  Do yourself a favor, don't get burned.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												I was looking for a multiplayer RTS that had no resources gathering but still kept strategic and tactical depths. CoH2 ticks all the boxes, with added brilliant graphics and audio to create one intense, immersive experience. Instead of resource gathering you have to capture certain territory points that when held give you the resources you need, such as manpower, munitions or fuel. You are then able to use these resource points to make building upgrades which then allow you to get better units or to upgrade your current units with special abilities. It’s very close to a MOBA actually, but with far more complexity.Concerning the campaign parts, it’s okay, but the game really shines in multiplayer, which by playing the campaigns helps you improve your multiplayer skills. The only negatives I can say about the game is that the tutorial should be better, especially to help people that are more interested in just playing multiplayer, and I almost stopped playing because of not quite knowing how it all worked. Also its mini tactical map, which is used consistently, greatly needs improvement, sometimes being very difficult to see where your units are. The larger tactical map is not practical to use so the mini map is mostly relied on and therefore needs to be clearer.
